content: The "National Park System Reform Act of 1994" is also known as the "National Park System Plan." This Act involves the preparation of a plan for the National Park System. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Director of the National Park Service, is tasked with preparing a National Park System Plan to guide the direction of the National Park System. The plan includes goals, objectives, and criteria for preserving national natural and cultural heritage. The National Park Service is tasked with defining its mission and role in preserving national natural and cultural heritage, determining criteria for including resources in the National Park System, and identifying adequate representation of different resource types in existing protected areas. The National Park Service is responsible for identifying appropriate natural and cultural resources for inclusion in the National Park System, determining adequate representation of different resource types, and prioritizing themes and resources to enhance the nation's heritage. Identification of appropriate aspects of the national heritage not currently represented in the National Park System, priorities of themes and resources to enhance the nation's heritage, and the role of the National Park Service in preserving natural areas, industrial America, cultural resources, and providing outdoor recreation opportunities. The National Park Service's role includes preserving natural areas, ecosystems, industrial America, nonphysical cultural resources, and providing outdoor recreation opportunities. The National Park System consists of units with distinctions from affiliated and other areas. The Secretary consults with various agencies and officials during plan preparation. The Secretary consults with various agencies and officials, including the National Park System Advisory Board, during the preparation of the plan. Consultations also involve public review and comment opportunities. The plan must be transmitted to Congress before the end of the third fiscal year after enactment. The Secretary consults with Advisory Board, resource management, recreation, and scholarly organizations, and other interested parties for public review and comment. The plan must be transmitted to Congress within three fiscal years after enactment. SEC. 102. MANAGEMENT REVIEW OF NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. The Secretary will review the National Park System to determine if there are better management alternatives, considering factors like duplication. A report will be developed listing areas where National Park Service management should be modified or terminated. The Secretary will develop a report listing areas in the National Park System where management should be modified or terminated, considering factors like duplication, lack of significance, cost, and visitor accessibility. The Secretary will develop a report listing areas in the National Park System where management should be modified or terminated based on factors like duplication, lack of significance, cost, visitor accessibility, and collaboration to protect resources. Recommendations for management by entities other than the National Park Service will be made for areas with national significance. Recommendations for management by entities other than the National Park Service will be made for areas with national significance. The Secretary shall consult with other Federal land managing entities in developing the list. The Secretary will identify feasible alternatives to National Park Service management for areas in the National Park System. Consultation with various stakeholders will be conducted, including Federal land managing agencies, State and local officials, and public review opportunities. The report must be transmitted to Congress within 1 year. The Secretary will consult with stakeholders to identify alternatives to National Park Service management for areas in the National Park System. The report must be transmitted to Congress within 1 year. The Secretary will transmit a report to Congress containing recommendations for modifications or termination of National Park Service management for areas within the National Park System, as well as recommendations for alternative management by other entities. SEC. 103. NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM REVIEW COMMISSION. Establishment of Commission: If the Secretary fails to transmit the report within the specified 1-year period, a National Park System Review Commission will be established to review existing units for better management alternatives. The Commission will prepare and submit a report to the House Natural Resources Committee and the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee within one year of its establishment. The Commission will prepare a report within one year of its establishment, listing National Park System units for potential modification or termination of National Park Service management. Alternative management suggestions by other entities will be included for listed areas. The Commission will develop a list of National Park System units for potential modification or termination of National Park Service management. The Commission established under this section includes per diem for government service, terminates 90 days after the report is sent to Congress, can hire staff with limitations on National Park Service employees, and may request staff from other agencies. SEC. 201. STUDY OF NEW PARK SYSTEM AREAS. Section 8 of the Act of August 18, 1970 is amended by inserting "General Authority.--" after "(a)", striking sentences two through seven of subsection (a), redesignating the last sentence as subsection (e) with "Authorization of Appropriations.--" added before "For the purposes of carrying". Section 8 of the Act of August 18, 1970 is amended by striking sentences two through seven of subsection (a), redesignating the last sentence as subsection (e) with "Authorization of Appropriations.--" added before "For the purposes of carrying", and by inserting a new subsection (b) for Studies of Areas for Potential Addition. The Act of August 18, 1970 is amended by adding a new subsection (b) for Studies of Areas for Potential Addition to the National Park System. The Secretary is required to submit a list of recommended areas for study at the beginning of each calendar year to the House and Senate Committees on Natural Resources and Energy. The list should prioritize areas with the greatest potential to meet national criteria. The Secretary of Energy and Natural Resources of the United States Senate is tasked with recommending areas for potential inclusion in the National Park System. Consideration is given to areas with the greatest potential to meet national significance, suitability, and feasibility criteria, with a focus on themes, sites, and resources not adequately represented in the current National Park System. The Secretary considers themes, sites, and resources for potential inclusion in the National Park System, focusing on areas not well represented. Studies for inclusion must be authorized by Congress, but preliminary assessments and data gathering are allowed. The National Park Service can initiate the inclusion of areas in the National Park System after the enactment of this section, with specific authorization from Congress. The Act does not limit the Service's authority to conduct assessments, gather data, provide assistance, prepare nominations, update studies, or complete surveys for areas costing less than $25,000. This section does not apply to river studies. The Secretary must complete studies for potential National Park System inclusion within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment. The Secretary must conduct studies for potential National Park System inclusion within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment, with public involvement and consideration of various factors for each area under study, including nationally significant natural or cultural resources, outstanding recreational opportunities, and suitability for addition to the system.
